references:
We consider two different scenarios for training the local model. In the first scenario, referred as IoT device local learning, local models are trained at the IoT devices and the F-APs upload the collected local model parameters to the CS for aggregation. In the second scenario, referred as F-AP local learning, the local models are trained at the F-APs based on the collected data from the IoT devices.
For both scenarios, we aim at minimizing the overall energy consumption of IoT devices and F-APs subject to FL time constraint, IoT device-RRB/F-AP scheduling, transmit power allocations, and computation frequency allocation. Such a joint optimization problem is NP-hard and thus, computationally intractable. By analyzing the problem of each scenario, we decompose it into two subproblems namely, resource scheduling and power
allocation subproblem and computation frequency allocation subproblem.

Let ğ’Ÿnsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›\mathcal{D}_{n} denote the local data set of IoT device nğ‘›n, which is a set of data samples {xi,yi}subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\{x_{i},y_{i}\}, where xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} is sample iğ‘–iâ€™s input (e.g., image
pixels) and yisubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–y_{i} is sample iğ‘–iâ€™s output (e.g., label of the image). Similar to [23, 25],
the local loss function on IoT device nğ‘›nâ€™s data set can be calculated as Lnâ€‹(Ï‰)=1Dnâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’Ÿnliâ€‹(Ï‰),âˆ€nâˆˆğ’©,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¿ğ‘›ğœ”1subscriptğ·ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›subscriptğ‘™ğ‘–ğœ”for-allğ‘›ğ’©L_{n}(\omega)=\frac{1}{D_{n}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{D}_{n}}l_{i}(\omega),\forall n\in\mathcal{N}, where Dn=|ğ’Ÿn|subscriptğ·ğ‘›subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›D_{n}=|\mathcal{D}_{n}| is the number of collected data samples by IoT device nğ‘›n and liâ€‹(Ï‰)subscriptğ‘™ğ‘–ğœ”l_{i}(\omega) is the loss function that measures the local training model error of data sample iğ‘–i. Then, IoT device nğ‘›n finds the optimum Ï‰nâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğœ”ğ‘›\omega^{*}_{n} that minimizes Lnâ€‹(Ï‰)subscriptğ¿ğ‘›ğœ”L_{n}(\omega) and uploads it to the suitable F-APs for aggregation by the CS. The IoT devices independently train local ML models based on their aggregated local data (e.g., images, videos, recorded audios). As shown in
Fig. 1, the specific process of FL in the tğ‘¡t-th iteration can be summarized as: 1) each IoT
device downloads the global model parameters Ï‰nâ€‹(tâˆ’1)subscriptğœ”ğ‘›ğ‘¡1\omega_{n}(t-1) from
the CS through the nearest F-AP; 2) each IoT device updates the local model by its
local training data and sends the updated local
model parameter Ï‰nâ€‹(t)subscriptğœ”ğ‘›ğ‘¡\omega_{n}(t) back to the F-APs; and 3) the CS aggregates the information from the F-APs and calculates the
new global model parameters.

We propose to minimize the total energy consumption for a delay-constrained FL. Specifically, our proposed framework intelligently selects the active IoT devices that perform local learning and assigns active IoT devices to the suitable F-APs.
Considering IoT device local learning scenario, the energy minimization problem can be formulated as

Solving problem ğ’«1subscriptğ’«1\mathcal{P}_{1} owing to its mixed combinatorial characteristics is challenging. Although exhaustive
search and branch-and-bound approaches can obtain near-optimal solution to ğ’«1subscriptğ’«1\mathcal{P}_{1}, such approaches are not suitable for the practical systems due to the significantly increased computational complexity. To strike a suitable balance between the required complexity and performance, we propose an iterative approach to solve problem P1 for large-scale IoT networks. To this end, we decompose ğ’«1subscriptğ’«1\mathcal{P}_{1} into the following two subproblems, namely, (i) IoT device scheduling and power allocation subproblem for a given IoT deviceâ€™ computation frequency allocation, and (ii) IoT deviceâ€™ computation frequency allocation subproblem for the determined power and IoT device scheduling.

ğ’«1subscriptğ’«1\mathcal{P}_{1} is solved by iteratively solving both subproblems ğ’«3subscriptğ’«3\mathcal{P}_{3} and ğ’«5subscriptğ’«5\mathcal{P}_{5} until convergence. The overall algorithm to obtain a suitable solution to problem ğ’«1subscriptğ’«1\mathcal{P}_{1} is provided in SectionÂ IV-C.

In subproblem ğ’«3âˆ’1subscriptğ’«31\mathcal{P}_{3}-1, Rtâ€‹h,nsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡â„ğ‘›R_{th,n} and Rtâ€‹h,jsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡â„ğ‘—R_{th,j} are the required uplink data rates for the nğ‘›n-th and jğ‘—j-th IoT devices, respectively; and Vğ‘‰V is a given weight factor. In particular, Rtâ€‹h,n=Tgâ€‹dnTq,kâˆ’Tgâ€‹Tlâ€‹Cnâ€‹Dnfnâˆ—subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡â„ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™subscriptğ¶ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›R_{th,n}=\frac{T_{g}d_{n}}{T_{q,k}-T_{g}T_{l}\frac{C_{n}D_{n}}{f_{n}^{*}}} and Rtâ€‹h,j=Tgâ€‹djTq,kâˆ’Tgâ€‹Tlâ€‹Cjâ€‹Djfjâˆ—subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡â„ğ‘—subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™subscriptğ¶ğ‘—subscriptğ·ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—R_{th,j}=\frac{T_{g}d_{j}}{T_{q,k}-T_{g}T_{l}\frac{C_{j}D_{j}}{f_{j}^{*}}}. Essentially, the rate constraints C8 and C9 satisfy the FL delay constraint C4. On the other hand, the weight factor Vğ‘‰V is selected to strike a suitable balance between capacity and energy consumption of the vertices.

In ğ’«6subscriptğ’«6\mathcal{P}_{6}, the optimization is over the continuous variables ğ©ğ©\bf p, and the discrete variables ak,nsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘›a_{k,n}, and sk,zn,âˆ€kâˆˆğ’¦,nâˆˆğ’©,zâˆˆğ’µformulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘§for-allğ‘˜ğ’¦formulae-sequenceğ‘›ğ’©ğ‘§ğ’µs^{n}_{k,z},\forall k\in\mathcal{K},n\in\mathcal{N},z\in\mathcal{Z}. It is still difficult to solve problem ğ’«6subscriptğ’«6\mathcal{P}_{6}
because of its non-convexity. To find a tractable solution to ğ’«6subscriptğ’«6\mathcal{P}_{6}, we develop an efficient algorithm in SectionÂ V-B.

In our simulations, we consider a hexagonal cell of radius 150015001500 m where F-APs and CS have fixed locations and IoT devices are distributed randomly within the cell. The CS is
located at the cell center. The channel model for IoT device-F-AP transmissions follows the standard path-loss model, which consists of three components: 1) path-loss of 128.1+37.6â€‹log10â¡(dis.[km])128.137.6subscript10dis.[km]128.1+37.6\log_{10}(\text{dis.[km]}); 2) log-normal shadowing with 444 dB standard deviation; and 3) Rayleigh channel fading with zero-mean and unit variance. The noise power, F-APâ€™s power, and maximumâ€™ IoT device power are assumed to be âˆ’174174-174 dBm/Hz and qk=pmax=3subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘max3q_{k}=p_{\text{max}}=3 W, respectively [25]. The weighting factor Vğ‘‰V is set to 0.30.30.3. The total number of global and local FL iterations are calculated as Tg=2â€‹Î²2(2â€‹Ï‘âˆ’Î²â€‹Î·)â€‹Ï‘â€‹Î·â€‹lnâ¡(1/Ïµg)subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”2superscriptğ›½22italic-Ï‘ğ›½ğœ‚italic-Ï‘ğœ‚1subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘”T_{g}=\frac{2\beta^{2}}{(2\vartheta-\beta\eta)\vartheta\eta}\ln(1/\epsilon_{g}), Tl=2(2âˆ’Î´â€‹Î²)â€‹Î´â€‹Ï‘â€‹lnâ¡(1/Ïµl)subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™22ğ›¿ğ›½ğ›¿italic-Ï‘1subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™T_{l}=\frac{2}{(2-\delta\beta)\delta\vartheta}\ln(1/\epsilon_{l}), respectively, with Î²=4,Î·=1/3,Î´=1/4,Ï‘=2,Ïµg=Ïµl=10âˆ’3formulae-sequenceğ›½4formulae-sequenceğœ‚13formulae-sequenceğ›¿14formulae-sequenceitalic-Ï‘2subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘”subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™superscript103\beta=4,\eta=1/3,\delta=1/4,\vartheta=2,\epsilon_{g}=\epsilon_{l}=10^{-3} [21]. The FL time threshold Tqsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{q} is 111 second [21]. The bandwidth of each RRB is 202020 MHz. Unless otherwise stated, we set the numbers of F-APs and RRBs to 999 and 444, respectively. The fronthaul capacity Rfâ€‹hsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘“â„R_{fh} is set to 150 Mbit/s. For each IoT device and each F-AP, the number of data samples Dnsubscriptğ·ğ‘›D_{n} is randomly chosen from 800800800 to 100010001000. Other parameters are summarized in Table I. To assess the performance of our proposed scenarios, we simulate various scenarios with different number of IoT devices Nğ‘N, data size ğ™³nsubscriptğ™³ğ‘›\mathtt{D}_{n}, number of RRBs Zğ‘Z, number of data samples Dnsubscriptğ·ğ‘›D_{n}, computation frequency allocation fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n}, fksubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜f_{k}, and parameter data size. For the sake of comparison, our
proposed schemes are compared with the following baseline schemes.

In Figs. 8-a and 8-a , we show the energy consumption
versus the number of CPU cycles for the first and second scenarios, respectively. The number of CPU cycles ranges from 2Ã—1072superscript1072\times 10^{7} to 10Ã—10710superscript10710\times 10^{7} in Fig. 8-(a) and from 2Ã—1092superscript1092\times 10^{9} to 10Ã—10910superscript10910\times 10^{9} in Fig. 8-(b). The number of CPU cycles determines the energy consumption.
Hence, the energy consumption of both fixed and power-only schemes, that fix the computation frequency allocation
at the highest value, is considerably increased with the increasing number of computation cycles. On the other hand, the energy consumption of both
CPU-only and proposed schemes with adjustable CPU frequencies do not change much as shown in Figs. 8-a and 8-b. As expected, using both transmit power and computation frequency allocation, our proposed schemes incur the least energy consumption for both small and large numbers of CPU cycles.
